Hi Rich - 

No, I don't recall seeing those at Choshuya but then my aging b=
rain was on its way to overload at that time.  I kind of figure "quality is=
 quality" and if it exists, enjoy and appreciate it. I'll be curious is the=
re was ever an article written about these miniatures. My friend (trained a=
s a goldsmith) seems to think one seppa is solid gold which if so, would in=
dicate something.

Ron
STL

an last October ( you were there as well so you may have

re were 2 nice examples of boys swords in Choshuya Ginza,

r good. They may have just been Koshirae, the grey

  Ron Hartmann wrote:
  >
  > Hi all -
  >
  > Quiet weekend. Thou=
ght I'd ask if anyone knows of any factual articles 
  > or simply some bac=
kground information on those miniature "Boys swords" 
  > that we sometimes=
 see from time to time. Some of these appear pretty 
  > low-end quality wh=
ile on occasion, some real workmanship shows up.
  >
  > Personally, I've n=
ever had much interest in these but recently, a very 
  > nice quality one =
was brought to me here in St. Louis by an antique 
  > appraiser friend. No=
w I own it. What impressed me was the nice quality 
  > of the fittings, th=
e baleen wrapping and a very handsome, well forged 
  > blade. The blade ap=
pears to be signed Bizen Osafune Morimitsu and is 
  > dated Oei 5 but more=
 likely, from what I've gathered, it is more 
  > likely a shinshinto creat=
ion made as a Morimitsu. Hamon is a narrow 
  > suguha with ko-nei with a b=
oshi swept in ko-nie (hakikake). Bo hi and 
  > an extended kissaki, male/f=
emale mekugi with "mellon" crest. Quite a 
  > nice "package" as we say.
  =
>
  > I've been told some of these were for export, but others were indeed =

  > made for presentation during coming-of-age. It would seem that 
  > so=
mebody would know more detail about these swords or perhaps know of 
  > an=
 authoritative article on them somewhere.
